column6: (Equivalent to ACTT 11000) Introduction to principles of accounting as they relate to financial accounting and the preparation of financial statements.

column4: ACCT 23020.
column6: (Equivalent to ACTT 11001) Introduction to principles of accounting as they relate to managerial accounting, including cost relationships.

column4: Cumulative 2.50 GPA; and ACCT 23020 or ACTT 11000; and ACCT 23021 or ACTT 11001; not open to accounting (ACCT) majors.
column6: Nontechnical presentation of federal income tax laws and regulations as they relate to individuals.

column4: Cumulative 2.50 GPA; and ACCT 23021 or ACTT 11001; and accounting (ACCT) major.
column6: The review of the accounting cycle; financial statement preparation, accounting for sales, receivables, inventory, current liabilities and fixed assets. Written communication and professional accounting research skills are emphasized.

column4: Cumulative 2.50 GPA; and ACCT 23021 or ACTT 11001;accounting (ACCT) major.
column6: Provides an overview of accounting information systems with emphasis on systems design and internal controls. Interpersonal skills and computer applications are emphasized.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and accounting (ACCT) major; and accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 33001 and ACCT 33004.
column6: Cost accounting for manufacturing and service organizations including cost determination, cost analysis and reporting costs for decision making planning and control. Ethical decision making and computer applications are emphasized.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 33001 and ACCT 33004.
column6: Accounting for long-term liabilities, debt and equity investments leases pensions and other post-retirement benefits income tax allocation and owners' equity statement of cash flows. Verbal communication and professional accounting research skills are emphasized.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and ACCT 23021 or ACTT 11001; not open to accounting (ACCT) majors.
column6: Issues relative to the balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement. Topics include assets, liabilities, owner's equity, revenue recognition, EPS, deferred taxes and pensions. Cannot be counted towards accounting major.

column2: COST CONTROL AND ANALYSIS FOR MANAGEMENT
column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and ACCT 23021 or ACTT 11001; not open to accounting (ACCT) majors.
column6: (Equivalent to ACTT 21063) Cost accounting concepts and procedures; analysis of revenue cost and income variances. Open only to non-accounting majors; cannot count towards accounting major.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and senior standing; and accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 33010 and ACCT 33012.
column6: Integration of concepts and practical aspects of auditing. The importance of strong controls is stressed. Ethical decision making and written communication skills are emphasized.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and senior standing ; and accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 33010 and ACCT 33012.
column6: Advanced techniques and issues in costing and accounting measurement for management planning, decision making and control. Professional accounting research, verbal communication and ethical decision-making skills are emphasized.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and senior standing; and accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 33001 and ACCT 33004 and ACCT 33010 and ACCT 33012.
column6: Emphasizes the analysis, design and implementation of accounting information systems and internal controls. Written communication, ethical decision-making and computer application skills are emphasized.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and senior standing; and Accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 33001 and ACCT 33004 and ACCT 33010 and ACCT 33012 and ACCT 43031.
column6: Business combinations, consolidated financial statements specialized disclosures foreign currency impacts inter-corporate investments. Professional accounting research and interpersonal skills are emphasized.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and senior standing; and Accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 33001 and ACCT 33004 and ACCT 33010 and ACCT 33012.
column6: Basic concepts of income recognition and deductions for individuals and corporations. Detailed coverage of the taxation of C corporations. Written communication skills are emphasized.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and senior standing; and Accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 43031.
column6: Advanced partnership and corporate tax problems; estate and gift taxation; tax administration and practice. Professional accounting research and written communication skills are emphasized.

column4: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and senior standing; and accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 33001 and ACCT 33004 and ACCT 33010 and ACCT 33012.
column6: Unique nonprofit, financial reporting, managerial accounting and financial and operating audits for government and nonprofit entities. Professional accounting research written communication and ethical decision making skills are emphasized.

column4: Junior standing and accounting (ACCT) major and special approval.
column6: Study of activities related to concurrent on-the-job experience with cooperating industrial and public accounting firms. Professional accounting research and written communication skills are emphasized.

column4: Senior standing and accounting (ACCT) major and special approval.
column6: To be determined when a specific course is proposed for a particular term.

column4: Senior standing and accounting (ACCT) major and special approval.
column6: Special topics course that will be offered periodically with different topics and different faculty involved each time the course is offered.

column4: Senior standing and accounting (ACCT) major and special approval.
column6: Open only to senior majors in accounting with permission of adviser.

column4: ACCT 33010 and 33012 or permission of instructor. Graduate standing.
column6: Advanced techniques and issues in costing and accounting measurement for management planning, decision making and control. Professional accounting research verbal communication and ethical decision making skills are emphasized.

column4: ACCT 33004 or permission of instructor. Graduate standing.

column4: ACCT 33012 and ACCT 43031; and graduate standing.
column6: Business combinations, consolidated financial statement; specialized disclosures; foreign currency impacts; inter corporate investments. Professional accounting research and interpersonal skills are emphasized.

column4: ACCT 43031 and graduate standing.
column6: Advanced partnership and corporate tax problems; estate and gift taxation; tax administration and practice. Professional accounting research and written communication skills are emphasized.

column4: ACCT 33012 and graduate standing.
column6: Unique nonprofit, financial reporting, managerial accounting, and financial and operating audits for government and nonprofit entities. Professional accounting research written communication and ethical decision making emphasized.

column4: Graduate standing and special approval.
column6: Special topics course that will be offered periodically with different topics and different faculty involved each time the course is offered.

column2: PROFESSIONAL ISSUES AND ETHICS IN ACCOUNTING
column4: Graduate standing and special approval.
column6: A capstone course for the MSA program. Investigates issues confronting the accounting profession today by reviewing the past, examining the present and looking into the future. Topics covered include history and characteristics of the profession, regulation of the profession, ethical challenges facing accountants and auditors, fraud and the future of the profession. Professional accounting research verbal, and written communication emphasized.

column4: graduate standing; and ACCT 43010 and ACCT 43014 or 53014.
column6: Examines the control and security of accounting information systems with an auditing perspective. Includes the role of IS audit function, IS auditing standards, system risks, application controls and current issues facing is auditors. Research, writing and ethics will be emphasized.

column2: ANALYSIS AND VALUATION OF BUSINESS USING FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
column4: ACCT 33001 or ACCT 63037; and graduate standing.
column6: Uses financial statements to analyze business strategy, accounting issues, finances and future prospects. Uses case studies to apply business valuation framework to security analysis, credit, corporate financing policies, and management communications. Research and writing will be emphasized.

column4: ACCT 33012; and graduate standing.
column6: Study of reporting in United States capital markets for domestic and foreign firms; evaluation of differences in accounting, auditing and financial reporting between nations; impact of international operations on accounting for decision making. Interpersonal skills emphasized.

column4: ACCT 43010; and graduate standing.
column6: Advanced conceptual and practical understanding of audit methodology and role of auditors. Focus on use of professional judgment in applying auditing standards on ethical considerations and on fraud. Review of current trends and developments in the public accounting profession. Written communication and ethical decision making emphasized.

column4: ACCT 33012 CORPORATE ACCOUNTING II Accounting for long-term liabilities, debt and equity investments leases pensions and other post retirement benefits income tax allocation and owners' equity statement of cash flows. Verbal communication and professional accounting research skills are emphasized. Prerequisite: cumulative 2.50 GPA; and accounting (ACCT) major; and ACCT 33001 and ACCT 33004.
column6: Survey of history of accounting and development of principles, followed by intensive study of theoretical problems related to determination of income and presentation of financial position. International and current issues also discussed. Written communication and ethical decision making emphasized.

column4: Open only to MBA and MA students; and graduate standing. Cannot be used toward MSA degree.
column6: In-depth study of financial accounting concepts and basic financial statements. Examination of significant accounting issues affecting financial reporting and their impact on analysis and interpretation of financial information for decision making.

column2: ACCOUNTING FOR MANAGERIAL ACTION AND EVALUATION
column4: ACCT 63037 or 73037; and MBA and MA students only; and graduate standing. Cannot be used toward MSA degree.
column6: Review of cost accounting concepts and cost behavior. In-depth study of analyzing costs for pricing and product mix decisions; activity based cost systems; budgeting; planning and control issues; methods of remaining competitive in a global environment; compensation issues.

column4: ACCT 43031 and graduate standing.
column6: An in-depth study of tax law that pertains to corporations and shareholders; corporate formation, distributions, liquidation and reorganization. Tax research and verbal and written communication emphasized.

column4: ACCT 43033 or ACCT 53033; and graduate standing.
column6: An in-depth study of formation, operation, termination and liquidation and other special problems of partnerships. Tax research and verbal and written communication emphasized.

column4: ACCT 43033 or ACCT 53033; and graduate standing.
column6: Tax planning; research methodology and problems. Tax research and verbal and written communications emphasized.

column4: ACCT 43033 or 53033; and graduate standing.
column6: Advanced tax coverage of C and S corporations and partnerships. The internal revenue code, treasury regulations and case law will be utilized in problem solving. Ethics, verbal communications and negotiating skills will be emphasized.

column4: enrollment in the M.S. in Accounting program; ACCT 33010 and 33012; and graduate standing.
column6: Supervised practical experience with public accounting firm, corporation, governmental, or not-for- profit organization. Periodic reports required.

column4: graduate standing and special approval.
column6: To be determined when a specific course is proposed for a particular term.

column4: graduate standing; and major in accounting.
column6: Review of sources, techniques and methodology. Individually selected topic is investigated and reported in formal paper which may extend beyond the semester.

column6: Library research and discussion will cover basic areas in cost/managerial accounting. Coverage will include a thorough understanding of the areas, the role of mathematical models, and emerging issues/problems. Emphasis will be placed on integrating the topical areas.
